awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Winston Leslie is "Periods of automorphic forms, relative trace formulas, and connections to geometry".  The host institution for the fellowship is Duke University and the sponsoring scientist is Jayce Getz.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A major theme in modern number theory is the exploration of arithmetic properties of numbers via analytic techniques. By applying robust tools from harmonic analysis, new and profound arithmetic information may be revealed. In the Langlands program, this connection is illustrated in the analytic and arithmetic theory of L-functions. In many cases, constructing these functions involves the study of distributions known collectively as period integrals of automorphic forms. Indeed, this idea goes all the way back to Riemann's integral formula for the eponymous zeta function in the 19th century.

In the global automorphic theory, the relative trace formula is a central tool for studying these periods. The strategy of comparison of relative trace formulae lies at the heart of the relative Langlands program. Nevertheless, the theory of the relative trace formula has still not been fully developed to meet the needs of the broader theory.

The goal of this project was to probe the existence of a theory of endoscopy in the context of the relative Langlands program; that is, to adapt the techniques of endoscopy and stabilization developed by Langlands, Shelstad, Kottwitz and other to the study of period integrals of automorphic forms. This is motivated by several examples of period integrals with potential applications to arithmetic properties of L-functions.
With this support, the PI succeeded in 

  • developing the first-ever theory of endoscopy for a relative trace formula. This is in the context of what are referred to as "unitary Friedberg-Jacquet periods," a rich family of examples with close ties to arithmetic geometry;  
  • establishing several tools for the analysis of relative orbital integrals and relative analogues of the Hitchin fibration; and
  • proving several results, including the fundamental lemma, toward the stabilization of a relative trace formula. 

Each of these results give strong evidence for a theory of relative endoscopy more generally, which continues to guide the PI's research. 

In a separate work, the PI studied non-linear Fourier transforms on certain singular spaces in joint work with Getz and Hsu. The outcome was to establish novel formulae and analytic properties of many examples of such transforms for spaces which play a central role in many period integral constructions. This research was motivated by the sweeping conjectures of Braverman-Kazhdan-Ngo-Sakellaridis on generalized Poisson summation formulae and applications to the analytic properties of L-functions.

Finally, the PI also collaborated with Pollack in developing a theory of modular forms on double covers of exceptional groups with a robust theory of Fourier coefficients (a special form of period closely modelled on the classical theory of modular forms) and constructing special examples with arithmetically rich invariants. This research provides potential connections between the large area of research into automorphic forms on covering groups and arithmetic. Both this and the prior collaborations were made possible by the project locating the PI at the sponsoring institution.

In terms of broader impacts, the PI had the opportunity to mentor graduate students of the sponsoring scientist Getz whose thesis work related to the notions of relative endoscopy at the core of this project. Additionally, the PI ran a undergraduate research project with an advanced student, serving as this student's undergraduate advisor. Finally, the PI co-organized an AMS special session in the spring of 2021 with the goal of gathering together young researchers in the area of automorphic representation theory.
